title: Your Home: How Long Should You Stay?
summary: After a punishing decline, the real-estate market is showing signs of stabilizing. In 2012's second quarter, home prices were 1.2% higher than a year earlier, according to S&P/Case-Shiller's national composite home-price index.
tag-1: Your Home: How Long Should You Stay?
tag-2: After a punishing decline, the real-estate market is showing signs of stabilizing. In 2012's second quarter, home prices were 1.2% higher than a year earlier, according to S&P/Case-Shiller's national composite home-price index.
tag-3: That's a far cry from the heady days of the housing bubble. Still, that doesn't mean a home can't be a way to build wealth even as it puts a roof over your head. But if you are tempted to buy your first home, trade up to a larger place or perhaps purchase a vacation property, you should probably think carefully about time horizon--because it can take many years of price gains to make up for the costs of first buying and later selling a home.
tag-4: As a buyer, your expenses can include home-inspection costs, mortgage-application fees, a title search, legal fees and moving costs, plus the costs of any initial repairs and redecorating. But it's selling that can really sting: Your expenses might include legal fees and any fixing up needed to make the place attractive. But the biggest hit will be the real-estate brokerage commission, which could be 5% or 6% of the selling price.
tag-5: Add it all up, and the roundtrip cost to buy and then sell a home could be 10% of a home's value. It might take five years to recoup that cost, assuming modest home-price gains. The bottom line: Before buying a home, you probably want to be reasonably confident that you'll stay put for at least that long--and preferably longer.
